Who We Are:
The Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs is the hub of Harvard Kennedy School's research, teaching, and training in international security and diplomacy, environmental and resource issues, and science and technology policy. From terrorism and nuclear weapons to cybersecurity, climate change, energy, and diplomacy, the Belfer Center provides research, ideas, and leadership for a more secure, peaceful world.

What We Do:
The Center has a dual mission: (1) to provide leadership in advancing policy-relevant knowledge about the most important challenges of international security and other critical issues where science, technology, environmental policy, and international affairs intersect; and (2) to prepare future generations of leaders for these arenas.

How We Do It:
The heart of the Belfer Center is its resident research community of more than 150 scholars, who through publications and policy discussions, workshops, seminars, and conferences, promote innovative solutions to significant international challenges.

Stay Connected:
- Receive our latest updates: https://belfercenter.org/subscribe
- Watch us on YouTube: https://youtube.com/BelferCenter
- See us on Instagram: https://instagram.com/belfercenter

With the U.S. Presidential elections behind us, we wrapped up last week at Harvard Kennedy School a three-session study group on U.S. Elections and Foreign Policy with Ambassador Wendy Sherman.

As the first woman to serve as U.S. Deputy Secretary of State, Ambassador Sherman brought a wealth of experience serving under three presidents and five secretaries of state. She’s widely recognized for her work in tackling challenging diplomatic issues, including her role as a key negotiator of the Iran nuclear deal.

During the sessions, we examined key U.S. foreign policy topics and analyzed the political messaging of both presidential candidates, particularly on what resonates with voters in swing states.

It was an excellent opportunity to learn and discuss the connections between foreign policy, U.S. elections, and their global impact with Ambassador Sherman, known as the diplomat for "hard conversations in hard places."
